title: UK Atmospheric NO2 — ECNNO2
text: UK Centre Ecolgoy & Hydrology

title: UK Atmospheric NO2 — ECNNO2
text: https://catalogue.ceh.ac.uk/documents/baf51776-c2d0-4e57-9cd3-30cd6336d9cf: "Atmospheric Nitrogen Dioxide data UK Environmental Change Network (ECN) terrestrial sites. data collected diffusion tubes ECN's terrestrial sites using standard protocol. represent continuous fortnightly records 1993 2015." data ECNNO2 NO2 (micrograms/m3). Note although dataset information state , believe data averaged iver time exposure (minutes), .e. micrograms/m3-minute, exposure time affect N02 values dataset, .e. longer exposure equal higher NO2 values.  link background information dataset. original data taken every 7-31 days, 14 days apart target common time difference.  ECNNO2 monthly average readings experimental tubes. average E1 tube average 1-3 E1 tubes month. E2, E3 etc. data part long-term monitoring program UK. N02 just one component monitored. sites locations ECNmeta.

title: UK Atmospheric NO2 — ECNNO2
text: Rennie, S.; Adamson, J.; Anderson, R.; Andrews, C.; Bater, J.; Bayfield, N.; Beaton, K.; Beaumont, D.; Benham, S.; Bowmaker, V.; Britt, C.; Brooker, R.; Brooks, D.; Brunt, J.; Common, G.; Cooper, R.; Corbett, S.; Critchley, N.; Dennis, P.; Dick, J.; Dodd, B.; Dodd, N.; Donovan, N.; Easter, J.; Flexen, M.; Gardiner, .; Hamilton, D.; Hargreaves, P.; Hatton-Ellis, M.; Howe, M.; Kahl, J.; Lane, M.; Langan, S.; Lloyd, D.; McCarney, B.; McElarney, Y.; McKenna, C.; McMillan, S.; Milne, F.; Milne, L.; Morecroft, M.; Murphy, M.; Nelson, .; Nicholson, H.; Pallett, D.; Parry, D.; Pearce, .; Pozsgai, G.; Rose, R.; Schafer, S.; Scott, T.; Sherrin, L.; Shortall, C.; Smith, R.; Smith, P.; Tait, R.; Taylor, C.; Taylor, M.; Thurlow, M.; Turner, .; Tyson, K.; Watson, H.; Whittaker, M.; Wood, C. (2017). UK Environmental Change Network (ECN) atmospheric nitrogen chemistry data: 1993-2015. NERC Environmental Information Data Centre. https://doi.org/10.5285/baf51776-c2d0-4e57-9cd3-30cd6336d9cf

title: UK Atmospheric NO2 — ECNNO2
code: # Data were prepared from the downloaded data set as follows: if (FALSE) { library(tidyr) library(reshape2) dat <- read.csv("ECN_AN1.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE) dat$Date <- as.Date(dat$SDATE, "%d-%B-%y") dat$Year <- format(dat$Date, "%Y") dat$Mon <- format(dat$Date, "%b") a <- subset(dat, TUBEID %in% c("E1","E2","E3")) b <- spread(a, FIELDNAME, VALUE) b <- b[order(b$Date), ] bad <- c(103, 104, 107:120) # bad quality codes. Burning nearby or contaminant in tube. b$NO2[b$Q1 %in% bad | b$Q2 %in% bad | b$Q3 %in% bad] <- NA val <- tapply(b$NO2, list(b$Year, b$Mon, b$TUBEID, b$SITECODE), mean, na.rm=TRUE) dat.mon <- melt(data=val, value.name="NO2") colnames(dat.mon) <- c("Year", "Month", "TubeID", "SiteCode", "Value") dat.mon$Date <- as.Date(paste(1,dat.mon$Mon, dat.mon$Year), "%d %b %Y") dat.mon <- dat.mon[order(dat.mon$Date),] rownames(dat.mon) <- NULL ECNNO2 <- dat.mon }  data(ECNNO2)

title: Mauna Loa C02 measurements — MLCO2
text: NOAA ESRL Trends Atmospheic Carbon Dioxide

title: Mauna Loa C02 measurements — MLCO2
text: monthly average C02 values recorded Mauna Loa Hawaii since 1958.  Data provided NOAA Earth System Rearch Laboratory, Global Monitoring Division. Data March 1958 April 1974 obtained C. David Keeling Scripps Institution Oceanography (SIO) obtained Scripps website (scrippsco2.ucsd.edu). ppm column contains monthly mean CO2 mole fraction determined daily averages.  mole fraction CO2, expressed parts per million (ppm) number molecules CO2 every one million molecules dried air (water vapor removed).  missing days, value interpolated value. See www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/ additional details.

title: Mauna Loa C02 measurements — MLCO2
text: Dr. Pieter Tans, NOAA/ESRL (www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/) Dr. Ralph Keeling, Scripps Institution Oceanography (scrippsco2.ucsd.edu/).

title: Mauna Loa C02 measurements — MLCO2
code: # We downloaded this data and created the `MLCO2` dataframe with the following code: if (FALSE) { library(RCurl) ## get CO2 data from Mauna Loa observatory ww1 <- "ftp://aftp.cmdl.noaa.gov/products/" ww2 <- "trends/co2/co2_mm_mlo.txt" CO2fulltext <- getURL(paste0(ww1,ww2)) MLCO2 <- read.table(text=CO2fulltext)[,c(1,2,5)] ## assign better column names colnames(MLCO2) <- c("year","month","ppm") save(MLCO2, file="MLCO2.RData") }  data(MLCO2)

title: Northern Hemisphere land and ocean temperature anomalies — NHTemp
text: https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cag/global/data-info: "Global temperature anomaly data come Global Historical Climatology Network-Monthly (GHCN-M) data set International Comprehensive Ocean-Atmosphere Data Set (ICOADS), data 1880 present. two datasets blended single product produce combined global land ocean temperature anomalies. available timeseries global-scale temperature anomalies calculated respect 20th century average."

title: Northern Hemisphere land and ocean temperature anomalies — NHTemp
code: # We downloaded this data and created the `NHTemp` dataframe with the following code: if (FALSE) { library(RCurl) ww1 <- "https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cag/time-series/" ww2 <- "global/nhem/land_ocean/p12/12/1880-2014.csv" NHTemp <- read.csv(text=getURL(paste0(ww1,ww2)), skip=4) save(NHTemp, file="NHTemp.RData") }  data(NHTemp)

title: Monthly and annual Chinook salmon commercial landings — chinook
text: two datasets included:  chinook.month chinook.year.  monthly data available 1990 annual data available 1950.  raw data R script process data inst/original_data folder. NOAA Fisheries Statistics Divison: "Collecting data joint state federal responsibility. State-federal systems gather landings data state-mandated fishery trip-tickets, landing weighout reports seafood dealers, federal logbooks fishery catch effort, shipboard portside interviews biological sampling catches. State fishery agencies usually main collectors data, though NOAA Fisheries gather data jointly states. Surveys done differently different states; NOAA Fisheries takes supplemental surveys ensure data different states years comparable." addition NOAA Fisheries Statistics Division: "Statistics state represent census volume value finfish shellfish landed sold dock, expanded estimate landings based sampling data. main statistics collected pounds ex-vessel dollar value landings identified species, year, month, state, county, port, water, fishing gear. states get landings data seafood dealers submit monthly reports weight value landings vessel. Increasingly, though, states getting landings data mandatory trip-tickets—filled seafood dealers fishermen end every fishing trip, indicating landings species."

title: Monthly and annual Chinook salmon commercial landings — chinook
text: NOAA Fisheries Office Science Technology, Commercial Landings Query, Available : www.fisheries.noaa.gov/foss, Accessed 14 April 2023 Pacific Fisheries Information Network (PacFIN) retrieval dated 14 April 2023, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission, Portland, Oregon (www.psmfc.org). Available https://reports.psmfc.org/pacfin

title: Monthly and annual Chinook salmon commercial landings — chinook
code: data(chinook) dat <- subset(chinook.month, state="WA")$log.metric.tons datts <- ts(dat, start=c(1990,1), frequency=12) plot(datts)   ggplot(   chinook.month %>%      mutate(t = zoo::as.yearmon(paste(Year, Month), "%Y %b")),   aes(x=t, y=log.metric.tons)) +   geom_line() +   facet_wrap(~State) #> Error in ggplot(chinook.month %>% mutate(t = zoo::as.yearmon(paste(Year,     Month), "%Y %b")), aes(x = t, y = log.metric.tons)): could not find function "ggplot"

title: Lake Washington Plankton Data — lakeWA
text: Monthly Lake Washington (WA, USA) plankton, temperature, total phosphorous, pH data 1962 1994.

title: Lake Washington Plankton Data — lakeWA
text: Object class "data.frame". #'

title: Lake Washington Plankton Data — lakeWA
text: lakeWA 32-year time series (1962-1994) monthly plankton counts Lake Washington, Washington, USA. lakeWA transformed version raw data (available MARSS package data(lakeWAplanktonRaw, package="MARSS")).  Zeros replaced NAs (missing).  plankton counts logged (natural log) standardized mean zero variance 1 (logged z-scored). Temperature, TP & pH also z-scored logged (z-score untransformed values covariates). single missing temperature value replaced -1 single missing TP value replaced -0.3. two missing pH values interpolated. Monthly anomalies temperature, TP pH computed removing monthly means (computed 1962-1994 period). anomalies z-scored remove mean standardize variance 1.

title: Lake Washington Plankton Data — lakeWA
text: Adapted Lake Washington database Dr. W. T. Edmondson, funded Andrew Mellon Foundation; data courtesy Dr. Daniel Schindler, University Washington, Seattle, WA. Hampton, S. E. Scheuerell, M. D. Schindler, D. E. (2006)  Coalescence Lake Washington story: Interaction strengths planktonic food web. Limnology Oceanography, 51, 2042-2051.

title: Lake Washington Plankton Data — lakeWA
code: # The lakeWA data frame was created with the following code: if (FALSE) { data(lakeWAplankton, package = "MARSS") lakeWA <- data.frame(lakeWAplanktonTrans) # add on month and date columns lakeWA$Month.abb <- month.abb[lakeWA$Month] lakeWA$Date <- as.Date(paste0(lakeWA$Year, "-", lakeWA$Month,"-01")) # interpolate 2 missing values in pH lakeWA$pH[is.na(lakeWA$pH)] <- MARSS::MARSS(lakeWA$pH)$states[1, is.na(lakeWA$pH)] # create monthly anomalies lakeWA$Temp.anom <- residuals(lm(Temp ~ Month.abb, data=lakeWA)) lakeWA$TP.anom <- residuals(lm(TP ~ Month.abb, data=lakeWA)) lakeWA$pH.anom <- residuals(lm(pH ~ Month.abb, data=lakeWA)) # resort the columns lakeWA <- lakeWA[,c(22,1:2,21,3:5,23:25,6:20)] # zscore everything for (i in 5:25) lakeWA[[i]] <- MARSS::zscore(lakeWA[[i]]) save( lakeWA, file="data/lakeWA.RData" ) }  library(ggplot2) library(tidyr) df <- lakeWA %>%       pivot_longer(          cols = Temp:Non.colonial.rotifers,          names_to = "variable",          values_to = "value"          ) ggplot(df, aes(x=Date, y=value)) +       geom_line() +       facet_wrap(~variable)      data(lakeWA)

title: Lake Barco Aquatic Data — neon_barc
text: Lake Barco data EFI 2021 Forecasting Challenge

title: Lake Barco Aquatic Data — neon_barc
text: neon_barc tibble columns date, siteID, oxygen, temperature, oxygen_sd, temperature_sd, depth_oxygen, depth_temperature, neon_product_ids, year, cal_day.

title: Lake Barco Aquatic Data — neon_barc
text: https://github.com/eco4cast/neon4cast-aquatics

title: Lake Barco Aquatic Data — neon_barc
text: data aquatics challenge comes NEON site Lake Barco (Florida). data challenge Github repository getting necessary data eco4cast. neon_barc data set created aquatics-targets.csv.gz file produced neon4cast-aquatics GitHub repository saved inst folder atsalibrary package. file, neon_barc created
code: library(tidyverse) library(lubridate) # This taken from code on NEON aquatics challenge targets <- readr::read_csv("aquatics-targets.csv.gz", guess_max = 10000) site_data_var <- targets %>%   filter(siteID == "BARC") # This is key here - I added the forecast horizon on the end of the data for the forecast period full_time <- tibble(time = seq(min(site_data_var$time), max(site_data_var$time), by = "1 day")) # Join the full time with the site_data_var so there aren't gaps in the time column site_data_var <- left_join(full_time, site_data_var) %>%   dplyr::rename(date = time) site_data_var$year <- year(site_data_var$date) site_data_var$cal_day <- yday(site_data_var$date) neon_barc <- site_data_var

title: Lake Barco Aquatic Data — neon_barc

title: Bristol Bay Sockeye Spawner-Recruit Data — sockeye
text: Spawner-recruit data sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) Bristol Bay region SW Alaska span years 1952-2005. data come large public database begun Ransom Myers many years ago. database now maintained RAM Legacy Stock Assessment Database. R script created data can found atsalibrary GitHub site inst/orginal_data/sockeye folder. convenience lab book, KvichakSockeye also created just Kvichak data.

title: Bristol Bay Sockeye Spawner-Recruit Data — sockeye
text: RAM Legacy Stock Assessment Database. 2018. Version 4.44-assessment-. Released 2018-12-22. Retrieved DOI:10.5281/zenodo.2542919. Ricard, D., Minto, C., Jensen, O.P. Baum, J.K. (2012) Evaluating knowledge base status commercially exploited marine species RAM Legacy Stock Assessment Database. Fish Fisheries 13 (4) 380-398. DOI: 10.1111/j.1467-2979.2011.00435.x Spawner escapement estimates originally : Bristol Bay Area Annual Management Reports Alaska Department Fish Game based river spawner counts (tower counts aerial surveys). See example application data see: Rogers, L.. Schindler, D.E. 2008. Asynchrony Population Dynamics Sockeye Salmon Southwest Alaska. Oikos 117: 1578-1586

title: Bristol Bay Sockeye Spawner-Recruit Data — sockeye
code: data(sockeye)  a <- pivot_longer(sockeye,      cols=spawners:recruits,      names_to="value",      values_to="count") ggplot(a,aes(brood_year, count, color=value, fill=value)) +    geom_area() +    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) +      ylab("Count (thousands)") +      xlab("Brood Year") +    facet_wrap(~region, scales="free_y") #> Warning: Removed 84 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_align()`).
